steps.title: Determine the size of Tallit that you will make.
steps.content: Determine the size of Tallit that you will make. Traditionally, a Tallit extends from the top of the head to the knees, but some extend only to above the buttocks. Keep in mind that type of Tallit that will be acceptable in your community or congregation.

steps.title: Determine the type of fabric.
steps.content: Determine the type of fabric. Tallits are normally made out of linen, wool, cotton or silk. Keep in mind that, according to Jewish law, wool and linen can't be combined.

steps.title: Cut fabric to the appropriate size.
steps.content: Cut fabric to the appropriate size. Hem the edges of the cloth, making sure to keep the hems small and not noticeable.

steps.title: Cut small reinforced holes on the 4 corners, in the middle.
steps.content: Cut small reinforced holes on the 4 corners, in the middle. Sew the corners.

steps.title: Choose the quote that will be used on the Atarah.
steps.content: Choose the quote that will be used on the Atarah. Suggestions for decorating the Atarah include embroidery, applique, batik (a wax-dyeing technique) or beading.

steps.title: Purchase the special string required for the tzitzit.
steps.content: Purchase the special string required for the tzitzit. This can be found online or at Judaica stores. Per the mitzvah (commandment) of tzitzit, the color of the thread must be techelet-blue. This is the color of the sky and symbolizes purity. Nevertheless, in most communities, only white strings are used.

steps.title: Lay out the tzitzit strings on a table or other flat surface.
steps.content: Lay out the tzitzit strings on a table or other flat surface. Place the 4 long tzitzit strings in one row and the 12 shorter ones in another.

steps.title: Stretch 1 long and 3 shorter tzitzit strings side by side, making the ends even on one side.
steps.content: Stretch 1 long and 3 shorter tzitzit strings side by side, making the ends even on one side. Before inserting that side into the prepared holes, quote the "leshem mitzvot tzitzit", meaning "for the purpose of the commandment of tzitzits."

steps.title: Pull through the 4 ends.
steps.content: Pull through the 4 ends. Make sure that they are as even as possible with the 3 shorter tzitzit ends on the other side. Make a temporary knot on the end where all 4 tzitzit strings meet together.

steps.title: Make sure that both ends of the shorter tzitzit strings are even.
steps.content: Make sure that both ends of the shorter tzitzit strings are even. Tie a double knot near the edge of the cloth near the hole. Wrap the long tzitzit string, or "shamash" around the other three string 7 times, and tie a double knot.

steps.title: Wrap the shamash around the other tzitzits 8 times and tie a double knot, then 11 times and tie a double knot.
steps.content: Wrap the shamash around the other tzitzits 8 times and tie a double knot, then 11 times and tie a double knot. Lastly, wrap it around 13 times and tie a double knot. The Sephardic custom is a 10-5-6-5 series of wraps.

steps.title: Untie the temporary knot to finish your first corner.
steps.content: Untie the temporary knot to finish your first corner. Repeat the process for the other 3.
